revision.text:
{{Use British English|date=November 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2016}} {{Infobox comedian | image = Omid Djalili 2010 Tribeca TFF Shankbone.jpg | caption = Djalili at the 2010 [[Tribeca Film Festival]] | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|df=yes|1965|09|30}} | birth_place = [[Chelsea, London]], [[England]] | occupation = Actor, comedian, television producer and writer | medium = Film, stand-up, television | subject = Religion, race, culture, stereotypes, human interaction | active = 1995–present }}
'''Omid Djalili''' ({{lang-fa|{{nastaliq|امید جلیلی|fa}}}}; born 30 September 1965)<ref>[https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0229084/ Omid Djalili profile] IMDb</ref> is a [[British people|British]] stand-up comedian, actor, television producer, voice actor and writer.
==Early life and education== Djalili was born in [[Chelsea, London]], to [[Iran]]ian [[Bahá'í Faith|Bahá'í]] parents and is a Bahá'í himself.<ref>[https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/profiles/omid-djalili-everybodys-fool-466169.html Omid Djalili: Everybody's fool] The Independent, 12 February 2006</ref><ref>[http://payvand.com/news/07/mar/1171.html In The Arena With Omid Djalili] By Darius Kadivar, Payvand's Iran News, 3 December 2007</ref> He attended [[Holland Park School]] and then the [[University of Ulster at Coleraine|University of Ulster]] in [[Coleraine]], [[Northern Ireland]], studying [[English language|English]] and [[Theatre|theatre studies]].<ref>''TV Heaven, Telly Hell'' – Omid Djalili</ref>
==Comedy career== {{BLP sources section|date=February 2011}} [[File:Omid Djalili at the Arts Depot in 2007.jpg|thumb|Djalili performing at the [[Arts Depot]] in 2007]] The first significant success of his stand-up comedy career was at the [[Edinburgh Festival Fringe]] in 1995 with "Short, Fat Kebab Shop Owner's Son", followed by "The Arab and the Jew" with Jewish comedian [[Ivor Dembina]] in 1996.<ref>{{cite web|title=Comedian Ivor Dembina| url=http://www.chortle.co.uk/comics/i/462/ivor_dembina|website=Chortle Comedy Website|accessdate=31 August 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Ivor Dembina shows|url=http://special.lib.gla.ac.uk/sta/search/detaile.cfm?EID=20456|website=University of Glasgow Scottish Theatre Archive}}</ref>
He has performed in numerous countries, including [[Australia]], [[Republic of Ireland|Ireland]], [[Sweden]], [[Belgium]], [[Canada]] and the [[United States]], where he had his own [[HBO]] Special and did 22 episodes of the [[NBC]] [[sitcom]] ''[[Whoopi]]'' with [[Whoopi Goldberg]].
He did his part for [[Comic Relief (charity)|Comic Relief]] after the [[2004 Indian Ocean earthquake and tsunami]] and also in 2005 he appeared on the British TV show ''[[Top Gear (current format)|Top Gear]]'' as a celebrity driver. The same year he broke Edinburgh Festival box office records with over 16,500 ticket sales.
In 2006, [[Sky Digital (UK & Ireland)|Sky Television]] picked him to be the face of their Saturday night film premières, and he also announced a new tour of the UK called 'No Agenda', from January 2007 until March 2007, covering 23 different dates. The ''No Agenda'' tour DVD was released in late 2007.
On 18 March 2007, he was voted by the British public as the 60th best stand-up comedian in a Channel 4 programme "The 100 Greatest Stand-Ups". On 26 October 2007, he guest-presented the BBC political quiz show ''[[Have I Got News for You]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b0084lxj|title=Have I Got News for You|publisher=BBC|accessdate=25 October 2013}}</ref> ''[[The Omid Djalili Show]]'' started on [[BBC1]] on 17 November 2007. The series was a mix of sketches and stand-up material. A second series was recorded in late 2008 and began broadcast on BBC 1 on 20 April 2009. He performed on ''[[We Are Most Amused]]'' on [[ITV1]] to mark [[Prince Charles]]'s 60th birthday in 2008.
==Acting career== Djalili has appeared in a number of films, most notably ''[[Gladiator (2000 film)|Gladiator]]'', ''[[The Mummy (1999 film)|The Mummy]]'', ''[[Mean Machine (film)|Mean Machine]]'', ''[[The World Is Not Enough]]'', ''[[Alien Autopsy (film)|Alien Autopsy]]'', ''[[Spy Game]]'', ''[[Sky Captain and the World of Tomorrow]]'', ''[[Grow Your Own (film)|Grow Your Own]]'', ''[[Notting Hill (film)|Notting Hill]]'', ''[[Mr Nice]]'', ''[[Pirates of the Caribbean: At World's End]]'', ''[[Sex and the City 2]]'' and provides his voice in ''[[Over the Hedge (film)|Over the Hedge]]''.
He had observed that he usually appears as a generic Middle Eastern background character in many of these films, often commenting that he appears in the [[The World Is Not Enough|James Bond film]] as the "Second Azerbaijani oil pipe attendant". He appeared as Nasim in the U.S. [[situation comedy|sitcom]] ''[[Whoopi]]'', starring Whoopi Goldberg, and picked up an international film award for Best Supporting Actor in ''[[Casanova (2005 film)|Casanova]]'', starring alongside [[Heath Ledger]] and [[Jeremy Irons]].
On 12 February 2009, producer [[Cameron Mackintosh]] announced that Djalili would appear as the second Fagin in the new [[West End theatre|West End]] production of ''Oliver!'' at the [[Theatre Royal, Drury Lane]], [[London]]. Omid took over from [[Rowan Atkinson]], who was contracted until 18 July 2009.<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/stage/2009/feb/11/omid-djalili-fagin-oliver "Omid Djalili pockets Fagin role in Oliver!"], ''The Guardian'', 11 February 2009</ref>
In 2009, Djalili became the voice of Yusuf Amir in the popular gaming series ''[[Grand Theft Auto]]''. He took up the role in the ''[[Grand Theft Auto: The Ballad of Gay Tony]]'' spin-off game. In 2010, he starred in the [[David Baddiel]] scripted film ''[[The Infidel (2010 film)|The Infidel]]''.
In 2010, Djalili starred in a series of TV and cinema adverts for [[Moneysupermarket.com]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/results?aq=f&search_query=moneysupermarketvids+omid+djalili&gl=US |title=Omid Djalili Money Supermarket adverts on YouTube |publisher=Youtube.com |date= |accessdate=2011-07-08}}</ref>
Djalili appeared in the short-lived NBC sitcom ''[[The Paul Reiser Show]]'', which was a midseason replacement for the 2010–11 television season.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thefutoncritic.com/news/2010/05/16/nbc-unveils-2010-2011-primetime-schedule/20100516nbc01/|title=NBC Unveils 2010-11 Primetime Schedule Accented by Five New Comedies, Seven New Dramas and New Alternative Program |date=16 May 2010 |work=The Futon Critic |accessdate=31 May 2010}}</ref>
For the BBC Learning project ''Off By Heart Shakespeare'', Omid played [[Lord Capulet]] from ''[[Romeo and Juliet]]'' and delivered the speech "Hang thee, young baggage, disobedient wretch!"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/schools/teachers/offbyheart/speeches/romeo_juliet_hang_thee.shtml |title=Schools – Teachers – Off By Heart Shakespeare: Romeo and Juliet "Hang thee, young baggage, disobedient wretch!" |publisher=BBC |date=2011-03-21 |accessdate=2011-07-08}}</ref>
Djalili appears in the Sky TV adaptation of ''Moonfleet'' shooting in Ireland in 2013.[http://www.rte.ie/ten/news/2013/0610/455765-sky-adventure-to-shoot-in-ireland/]
He appeared in the second season of ''[[Thunderbirds Are Go (TV series)|Thunderbirds Are Go]]'' in October 2016 as Horse Williams.{{citation needed|date=December 2016}}
Djalili provided his voice in the 2015 stop motion animated comedy ''[[Shaun the Sheep Movie]]''.
In 2017 Djalili appeared in an acclaimed performance of ''[[Fiddler on the Roof]]'' at the [[Chichester Festival Theatre]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cft.org.uk/archive/fiddler-on-the-roof|title=Fiddler on the Roof {{!}} Chichester Festival Theatre|last=Supercool|date=2017-12-02|website=Chichester Festival Theatre|language=en-gb|access-date=2017-12-03}}</ref>.
==Other activities== In 2008, he was an official festival judge for the [[Noor Iranian Film Festival]]. In June 2010, Djalili appeared in a [[Meltdown Festival]] concert<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.southbankcentre.co.uk/find/music/classical/tickets/philharmonia-orchestra-hovhaness-53197 |title=Philharmonia Orchestra: Hovhaness |publisher=Southbank Centre |date=2010-06-13 |accessdate=2014-07-29}}</ref> given by the [[Philharmonia Orchestra]] at London's [[Queen Elizabeth Hall]], performing the part of the narrator in 'Rubaiyat', a [[symphonic poem|tone poem]] by American classical composer [[Alan Hovhaness]] which sets the words of [[Omar Khayyám]] to music. He also appeared on the ''[[Graham Norton Show]]'' on 17 February 2012, alongside [[Daniel Radcliffe]] and [[Cuba Gooding Jr.]].
==Awards== Djalili has won awards for his comedy. These include the [[EMMA Award]], ''[[Time Out (company)|Time Out]]'' Award, and [[London Weekend Television|LWT]] Comedy Award for Best Stand-up Comedian, Spirit of the Fringe Award as well as the One World Media Award for his [[Channel 4]] documentary, ''Bloody Foreigners''.
He has also been nominated for awards, such as the [[Perrier Award]] for Best Comedian, the Gemini Award for Best Comedy Performance of 2003, the South Bank Award for Best Comedy of 2003, the [[Royal Television Society]] Award for Best Stand-up, and the European TV Award for his ''Bloody Foreigners''.
==Personal life== Djalili is a [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] fan and has appeared many times in the club's in-house channel, [[Chelsea TV]].<ref>''Fenners meets Omid Djalili'', ESPN (UK), 19 April 2010</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Sk4DDioM_2I |title=Omid Djalili at the Edinburgh International Book Festival |publisher=Youtube.com |date= |accessdate=2017-11-01}}</ref>
